justification: The Methods section states: "Self-control was measured using the Brief Self-control Scale (BSCS)." This sentence explicitly links the construct of self-control to the BSCS instrument.

Under Materials it is noted: "Financial Literacy was measured using a questionnaire adapted from Fernandes et al., (2014) which comprises 13 items representing a reliable unidimensional construct of financial literacy," indicating that this questionnaire operationalises the financial-literacy construct.

The article reports: "Subjective Numeracy was measured using the Subjective Numeracy Scale, developed by Fagerlin et al., (2007)," directly connecting the construct of subjective numeracy with that specific scale.

In the study overview it says: "Participants are prompted with either low or high construal exercises using a 'Why/How' task paradigm," showing that the Why/How task is the procedure used to elicit (and hence operationalise) different construal levels.

The Materials section describes a block of coin-toss trials and notes that "The binary outcome variable was if participants chose to gamble during the coin-toss task (Gamble / No Gamble)," indicating the coin-toss task serves as the measure of risk-taking behaviour.
